Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 2/25/2025 at 7:00pm, the assistant program manager for the
DART Program gave Youth A another child's medication. Staff at
the DART Program contacted poison control and Youth A was
brought to the hospital. Youth A was released at 12:00am on
2/26/2025 with no medical concerns.
Investigation Case Manager was interviewed via phone on 2/26/2025. She
reported learning about the allegations during the team meeting
the next morning and calling Department of Health and Human
Services (DHHS) about the allegations. She also reported
understanding Supervisor 1 passed the wrong medication to
Youth A at approximately 7:00 pm last night, 2/25/25. She also
reported Youth A was taken to the hospital and released after
being assessed for ingesting the wrong medication.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 2/26/2025. She
reported Supervisor 1 is no longer allowed to pass medications
because Case Manager informed her of the mistake that was
made by Supervisor 1. She also reported Supervisor 1 is a young
supervisor who may have been distracted because of reported
family issues. She reported planning on having all staff retrained
on passing medication.
Administrator 1 was interviewed again via video conference
on 2/27/2025. She reported Nurse is scheduling a refresher
training for passing medication which is mandatory for staff
working the unit Supervisor 1 covers. She also reported Nurse
came in today and is observing all medication passing to assess
staff’s passing of medication.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via video conference on
2/27/2025. She reported passing the medication prepared for
Youth B to Youth A, causing the incident. She reported there were
3-youth on the unit at the time and after preparing the medication
for Youth B she turned and walked to the door and for some
unknown reason called Youth A to take the medication. She
reported checking to ensure identification of Youth A was made
2

(again wrong youth the medication was prepared for). Upon
returning to the computer screen, she noticed Youth B’s
information was on the screen which caused her to realize she
had made a mistake by giving the medication to Youth A. She was
unable to explain any reason for this mix-up. She also reported
following all medication procedures when preparing the
medication and the mistake occurred when reaching the door and
mixing up the two youth (Youth A and Youth B). She reported
once realizing the mistake, she followed procedures and called
Nurse and Manager of Program Operations. She also reported
calling Poison Control and then taking Youth A to the hospital.
She reported the process for passing medication as pulling each
youth’s medication drawer individually and pulling out the blister
packs of medication. She enters the youth into the medication
program matching the medication to the medication listed in the
program. Once matched, she scans the blister pack and removes
a pill. She places the pill in the medication cup and moves to the
next medication if there is more than one. She then takes the
medication and moves to the door to administer the medication. At
the door she verifies the identity of the youth before giving the
medication.
Manager of Program Operations was interviewed via video
conference on 2/27/2025. He reported receiving a call from
Supervisor 1 informing him of the medication error. Supervisor 1
also reported giving Youth B’s medication to Youth A who
ingested the wrong medication. He reported speaking with
Supervisor 1 again on the way to the hospital. He also reported
being Supervisor 1’s supervisor and that Supervisor 1 has always
been “steady” as an employee. He reported Supervisor 1 has
been working through personal matters over the past couple of
months and if he believed she is not doing well, he would send
Supervisor 1 home and find coverage for her. He did not report
having to take this action in the past few months.
Nurse was interviewed via video conference on 2/27/2025.
She reported receiving a phone call from Supervisor 1 right after
the incident occurred, about giving Youth B’s medication to Youth
A. She also reported Supervisor 1 informed Nurse that Poison
Control indicated Youth A should be taken to the hospital. Nurse
reported checking on Youth A the next morning and finding him to
have no side effects and feeling “alright”. Nurse also went through
the process of passing medication which is described below.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/27/2025. Youth A reported going to the hospital yesterday
3

because he was given the wrong medication. Youth A also
reported feeling good and doing well. Youth A reported feeling
safe at the facility and being taken care of by the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
Hope Network Medication Administration and Control C-
117.BHW dated 7/15/21. The focus of this document is to outline
the procedures for administering prescription and over-the-counter
alternative medications to youth who do not administer their own
medication. It is documented that staff are to positively identify the
youth served using two identifiers before the medication is
administered. Staff are also to explain to the youth (even when
non-verbal) what medication the physician ordered. It is
documented that staff are to prepare one youth’s served
medications at a time. The training required to engage in
medication passing is outlined which involves staff signing that
they understand this policy. There are several steps involved in
the training that involve oversight by trained staff, completion of 10
shadow medication passes, and completion of a “Final Medication
Pass Quiz” with a score of 80%.
Hope Network Medication Adverse Reactions C-118.BHW
dated 1/13/20. The focus of this document is to outline the
procedures of consistency in reporting medication errors, charting
errors, and guidelines for corrective action regarding the errors. It
is documented that all medication errors will be tracked using the
“Medication Error Tracking Form”. At the beginning of each shift
the staff responsible for medication passing is required to check
the missed medication section in the Electronic Medication
Administration System. If staff make a medication error staff are
required to acknowledge the error and assess the youth by taking
all vitals, complete a visual assessment of the youth status, call
Poison Control and follow directions, complete an Incident Report
(IR), and contact Nursing on-call.
Hope Network Developmental Adolescent Residential
Treatment Health Services Policy and Procedure dated
9/11/24. This document outlines the overall guidelines for medical
services at the facility. It documents staff are to follow the incident
report policy/procedure regarding documentation of adverse
events (see above). Staff are to provide their initials when
administering medication which is to be entered at the time the
medication is given. It is documented that all staff who are trained
to administer medication are to administer medication as outlined
in the Hope Network Medication Administration and Control C-
4

117.BHW dated 7/15/21 policy. These trained staff are also to
complete the competency assessment.
Incident Report date of incident 2/25/25 @ 7:00 pm for Youth
A. It is documented that Supervisor 1 was passing medication and
called Youth A up to the door to get medication. Supervisor 1
provided medication to Youth A and Youth A took medication
before walking away. Supervisor 1 went back to the medication
cart and noticed she had given the wrong medication (Youth B’s
medication) to Youth A. It is documented that Supervisor 1 called
Nurse on-call to report the medication error and was advised to
call poison control. Before calling poison control Supervisor 1
called Manager of Program Operations Program Manager and
then called poison control. Poison control directed Supervisor 1 to
take Youth A to the Emergency Room. Youth A was at the
Emergency Room from 7:40 pm to a little after 12:00 am. The staff
at the Emergency Room advised Supervisor 1 that Youth A could
still take Youth A’s 7:00 pm medication which was given to Youth
A before Youth A went to bed.
After Visit Summary Helen DeVos Children’s Hospital dated
2/25/25 for Youth A. This document indicates Youth A was seen
for accidental drug ingestion and a comprehensive metabolic
panel for Youth A’s lithium level was completed and an
electrocardiogram was completed. A follow up appointment was
scheduled for 3/21/25 with the physician.
Nurse provided a demonstration of the procedure for passing
medication during a video conference on 2/27/2025. Nurse
opened the laptop on the desk and started the computer. The
medication program Medication Administration Record (MAR) and
a list of youth appeared. She picked a youth from the list one at a
time which is the procedure, and a list of the medications
appeared on the computer. She then opens the drawers and
pulled out the blister packs for the selected youth. She then
matched the name on the blister packs to the youth and
medications listed on the screen. She then scanned the blisters
pack before taking the pill out of the blister pack. The pill is then
placed in the medication cup. As each medication is scanned, a
check is made on the medication on the screen. Once all the
medication is in the cup, she then walks to the door and seeks the
youth. She checks with the youth to ensure their name and
medication is correct before giving medication to the youth. She
reported the need for 2 identifiers when finding the youth which
can include the youth’s name, date of birth, staff identifying the
youth, and a picture option.
5

Meds & Vitals Refresher dated 2/13/25. This is the sign in sheet
for this refresher training and Supervisor 1’s signature is present
along with 6 other staff.
Hope Network BHS Annual Refresher Post-test dated 2/13/25
for Staff 1. There are 13-questions and Supervisor 1 was able to
correctly answer each question.
Medication Administration Record (MAR) for the February
2025 for Youth A. This document outlines the medications given,
time of medication, and who administrated the medication to
Youth A. This document also lists Youth A’s date of birth and
“Resident ID” number. This document also lists other actions
taken with Youth A such as trimming nails weekly, bowel
movements, checking braces, and over the counter medication
such as Milk of Magnesia, Ibuprofen, Tylenol, Benadryl,
Hydroxyzine, Melatonin, Nayzilam, Polyethylene Glycol, Saline
Nasal spray, Robitussin, and Tums if any of these OTC
medications are given. Exceptions for Youth A are also listed on
this document.
Treatment provided for Youth A at Emergency Room dated
2/25/25. It is documented Youth A presented as unremarkable
and just feeling tired. An EKG was completed which showed an
appropriate ventricular rate, normal PR, and no ST elevations. A
lithium level was checked and documented as abnormal with a
result value of 0.42 which is below the normal value of 0.60-1.20.
(Youth A was provided Lithium upon a return to the facility that
evening) All other components are within normal range.
HR record for Supervisor 1 was reviewed. Supervisor 1 was
hired on 9/12/2006. There was one disciplinary action
documented in her personnel file. This “verbal coaching” is
documented as occurring on 2/21/24 and involves Supervisor 1
not checking and approving timecards for those Supervisor 1
supervises. It is documented Supervisor 1 is to review staff’s
timecards and address any concerns found. It is documented
Supervisor 1 refused to sign this “verbal coaching” form on
2/22/24. She is current on all required trainings and just completed
a meds refresher on 2/13/25.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed in the facility through a video
conference since there is a high rate of youth and staff
experiencing flu like symptoms. The medication process was
6

reviewed through the video conference and Youth A was
observed outside of the facility.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as evidence by interviews
with staff, youth, document reviews, and video review of the
medication process. Supervisor 1 admitted to providing the wrong
medication to Youth A resulting in the violation. Other than
providing the wrong medication, Supervisor 1 followed the facility’s
policy/procedure for passing medication. This action could be
accomplished by a check in process with the supervisor at the
beginning of a shift.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was offered to the facility in the aspect of
ensuring staff are of sound mind when beginning a shift especially
staff involved in delicate activities such as passing medication. If a
staff is struggling with personal issues, they should be relieved of
a delicate assignment and to make sure the supervisor is aware of
possible issues of deregulation for the staff.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
